meanings.def: on or to the inner part of something/somebody; within something/somebody
examples: Go inside the house.
Inside the box was a gold watch.
For years we had little knowledge of what life was like inside China.
You'll feel better with a good meal inside you.
(figurative) Inside most of us is a small child screaming for attention.

meanings.def: in less than the amount of time mentioned
examples: The job is unlikely to be finished inside (of) a year.
She shook it to make sure there was nothing inside.
He went inside (= indoors) to get his car keys.
‘Get inside!’ he said and closed the door.
We had to move inside (= indoors) when it started to rain.
(figurative) I pretended not to care but I was screaming inside.
He was sentenced to three years inside.

meanings.def: the inner part, side or surface of something
examples: The inside of the box was blue.
the insides of the windows
The cake has a slight crust while the inside is soft and moist.
PVC is used in dishwashers for lining the inside.
from the inside The door was locked from the inside.
on the inside The shell is smooth on the inside.

meanings.def: the part of a road nearest the edge, that is used by slower vehicles
examples: on the inside He tried to overtake on the inside.

meanings.def: the part of a curved road or track nearest to the middle or shortest side of the curve
examples: on the inside The French runner is coming up fast on the inside.
She was so nervous, her insides were like jelly.
He complained of a pain in his insides.

meanings.def: with the part that is usually inside facing out
examples: You've got your sweater on inside out.
Turn the bag inside out and let it dry.

meanings.def: to be very familiar with somebody/something
examples: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

meanings.def: belonging to a group or an organization and therefore able to get information that is not available to other people
examples: The thieves must have had someone on the inside helping them.

meanings.def: to make a place very untidy when you are searching for something
examples: The burglars had turned the house inside out.
The new manager turned the old systems inside out.

idioms.def: with the part that is usually inside facing out
examples: You've got your sweater on inside out.
Turn the bag inside out and let it dry.

idioms.idiom: know somebody/something inside out | know somebody/something like the back of your hand
idioms.def: to be very familiar with somebody/something
examples: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

idioms.def: belonging to a group or an organization and therefore able to get information that is not available to other people
examples: The thieves must have had someone on the inside helping them.

idioms.def: to make a place very untidy when you are searching for something
examples: The burglars had turned the house inside out.
The new manager turned the old systems inside out.

meanings.def: forming the inner part of something; not on the outside
examples: the inside pages of a newspaper
an inside pocket
(British English) I was driving in the inside lane (= the part nearest the edge, not the middle of the road).

meanings.def: known or done by somebody in a group or an organization
examples: inside information
Any newspaper would pay big money to get the inside story on her marriage.
The robbery appeared to have been an inside job.
